keyTakeAways: Education is a civil rights issue, as low-income students are systematically underrepresented in elite universities despite having equal academic potential.
NEON brings college-level courses directly into underresourced schools, especially Title I schools, to improve college access and confidence.
Students who complete NEON courses are twice as likely to attend four-year colleges and persist in college compared to peers from similar backgrounds.
Despite limited funding and staff (32 full-time employees), NEON has expanded to 33 states and operates in all Title I schools in Jackson, Mississippi, and 120 in New York City.
NEON's model is more effective than traditional Advanced Placement programs, which often fail low-income students due to high-passing thresholds and one-test grading.

namedEntities.name: Leslie Cornfeld
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Founder and lead executive of the National Education Opportunity Network (NEON); former advisor to New York City Mayor Michael Bloomberg and U.S. Education Secretaries during the Obama administration.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: She identified the systemic gap in college access for low-income students and founded NEON to address it by bringing elite university courses into high schools.

namedEntities.name: National Education Equity Lab
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A nonprofit launched in 2019 by Leslie Cornfeld with $50,000 from the Carnegie Corporation of New York.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: This lab evolved into NEON and pioneered the initiative to deliver college-level courses to underresourced high schools.

namedEntities.name: National Education Opportunity Network (NEON)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The rebranded and expanded version of the National Education Equity Lab, delivering college credit-bearing courses to Title I high schools.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: NEON serves over 40,000 students across 33 states, with a goal to reach 1 million students in 10 years, directly addressing college access inequities.

namedEntities.name: Carnegie Corporation of New York
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A major foundation that provided initial funding and support to the National Education Equity Lab.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Provided $50,000 in startup funding and has continued to support NEON with additional grants ($200,000 in 2021 and $3 million in 2024).

namedEntities.name: Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A major philanthropic foundation that has contributed to NEON’s funding pool.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Provided financial support as part of broader philanthropic efforts to improve educational equity.

namedEntities.name: NBA
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A sports organization that has contributed to NEON’s funding.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Demonstrates public-private collaboration in education reform, showing support from non-educational sectors.

namedEntities.name: Apollo Foundation
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A philanthropic foundation that has contributed to NEON’s funding.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Supports NEON’s mission through financial backing, reflecting trust in the model’s scalability and impact.

namedEntities.name: Morgan Stanley
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A financial institution that has contributed to NEON’s funding.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Shows institutional investment in equitable education, signaling confidence in NEON’s impact and sustainability.

namedEntities.name: Henry McCance
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A venture capitalist and individual benefactor of NEON, who has provided significant financial support.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: His backing reflects a shift in private investment toward education equity, particularly from tech and venture capital sectors.

namedEntities.name: Harvard College
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: One of the elite universities that offers courses to students through NEON.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Harvard's poetry class is among the first courses delivered to high schools, symbolizing access to elite institutions.

namedEntities.name: Raj Chetty
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Economist whose 2017 analysis of over 30 million college students showed that elite colleges are least socioeconomically diverse.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: His research provided the data foundation for Cornfeld’s belief that opportunity, not talent, is the key barrier to college access.

namedEntities.name: Advanced Placement (A.P.) Program
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A standardized college prep program that has failed low-income students in the past.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: NEON’s model is positioned as a more effective alternative, with 60% of A.P. exams by low-income students failing to earn college credit.

namedEntities.name: Title I High Schools
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Public schools with high percentages of low-income students, targeted by NEON.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: NEON operates specifically within these schools to increase college access and academic confidence for disadvantaged students.

namedEntities.name: Robert Balfanz
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Researcher from Johns Hopkins who conducted a five-year study on NEON student outcomes.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: His research found that NEON students are twice as likely to attend four-year colleges and persist in college.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Leslie Cornfeld, a former federal civil rights prosecutor and advisor to New York City Mayor Michael Bloomberg and President Obama’s education secretaries, founded the National Education Equity Lab in 2019 with a $50,000 grant from the Carnegie Corporation of New York. The initiative, now known as the National Education Opportunity Network (NEON), brings college-level courses from 17 elite universities—including Harvard—directly into Title I high schools. Over five years, NEON has delivered over 40,000 courses to students across 33 states, with 80% of students passing. NEON students are twice as likely to attend four-year colleges and persist in college compared to peers, addressing the systemic inequity where elite universities remain underrepresented by low-income students. Despite limited funding—only $7.5 million in 2024 and 32 full-time staff—NEON has gained support from major foundations and individuals like Henry McCance. The program has expanded to all Title I schools in Jackson, Mississippi, and 120 in New York City, and aims to serve 1 million students in 10 years. NEON’s model, which builds student confidence and college readiness through direct access to elite coursework, is seen as a more effective alternative to the failing Advanced Placement system, particularly for students from rural, poor, and marginalized communities.
title: How a Network of College Courses Is Closing the Gap for Low-Income Students
